bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to the Director of Health (Direccion de Salubridad), September 9, 1921

div1.p: Hanson gives an account of his trip to Panama. He mentions a modification of quarantine process. He describes sanitary inspections to various regions of Peru [lists names of personnel]. He expresses concern about the government's funding of workers. The yellow fever campaign is going well, but vigilance is required.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to the Director of Health (Direccion de Salubridad), September 9, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
---
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----
Chiclayo, Peru.
September 9,1921
Direccion de Salubridad,
Lima, Peru.
Sir:
div1.p:
I beg to report that I returned from Panama to my Chiclayo Office on the
second of September. On this trip I left Callao on the evening of the 9th of
August and arrived in Panama on the morning of the 14th of the same month.

While in Panama I had several interviews with the Health Authorities
of the Panama Canal Zone, who were very much interested in the progress of the
yellow fever campaign, as well as in other important sanitary problems on the
Pacific Coast of South America and particularly in Peru. After a few conferences
with the Chief Quarantine Officer of the Canal Zone, he issued orders lifting,
or probably more correctly speaking, moderating the quarantine against Peruvian
ports. I presume that you will have received copies of this modification before
this letter will reach you. The effect of the modification was that passengers
from Peruvian ports will not be taken to the quarantine station as the practice
had been before, but that the would be put under a six day observation at their
residence, and would be allowed to travel freely in Panama Colon of the Canal
Zone. Indications are that even this restriction will be removed if the work
continues satisfactory in the prophylactic campaign, if not the old restrictions.
will be reestablished.

On the return trip my ship called at Port of Pizarro, and since the
port authorities had not made proper preparation to receive the ship, we were
delyed an extra day in this port. I took advantage of this delay to visit and
inspect Tumbes. I was agreably disappointed in Tumbes. It is a place of better
than the average construction on the northern coast of Peru, and is cleaner than
most town which I have seen with the exception of Trujillo. It has an abundant
supply of water in the river (Rio Tumbes) and the land bordering the rives has

the appearance of fertile productive land. It is rather
surprising that so little effort is made to cultivate this land, where there is
so much available water in the river.

Investigation for cases of suspicious illness resulted negatively.
In my brief investigation it was apparent that the stegomya breeding was low,
and I do not think that this Province constitutes any menace to the outcome of
the campaign on the coast. While there I gave a few simple instructions to the
man who said he was in charge of the anti-stegomya work - I advised him to be-
gin the liberal distribution of fish in all doubtful palces and containers. He
promised to do this, and if he does the stegomya problem will soon be solved.
The Port of Pizarro is a very small place and of no importance as a focus of infection.

On account of the rumor which Dr. Laverbaia reported to me, of a case
of yellow fever in Buena Ventura last year, I went ashore while we were in this
port and made a few inquiries and such inspections as was possible. I walked over
practically the entire town making mental notes of sanitary conditions. It is a
place which undoubtedly is heavily infected with malaria, on account of the many
small swampy areas among the low hills on which the town is built. I saw no
evidence of any profuse stegomya breeding. Inquiries faild to indicate that there
had been any cases of yellow fever for several years. The case which gave rise
to last years rumor was that of the death of the British Consul, where some of the
local physicians made a diagnosis of yellow fever. This man had been subject to
heart and liver trouble and had had repeated attacks of the same kind of illness
as that in which he died. His last illness had a duration of about a month, and
that in itself would exclude yellow fever. Dr. Smith, who has a hospital at La
Cumbre said that he had previously attended him in an accack like that in which
he died and said that he thought the diagnosis of yellow fever and error. No other
cases were reported.

At paita I went ashore and had a conference with Dr. Reinese, who seems to

be of the opinion that the work in Paita has been somewhat
neglected, but states that he has neither seen nor heard of any suspicious cases
of yellow fever this year. Dr. Caballero is at present in the Department of Piura
and will investigate all important points in the Department before returning to
his post in Ancash and the northern section of the Department of Lima. On account
of the short stay of the ship I was unable to make any further personal investi-
gations.

Here in the Department of Lambayeque I am glad to say that the work is
continuing to progress as well as one could wish. Our mosquito index is now down
to and even below 1% in all the principal places. Recently we have distributed
a great many fish, up to the present writing we have distributed about one hundred
fifty thousand fish as larvae consumers. It is the surest and the most effective
method, but even with that we meet considerable resistance on the part of some
people. All the data has not yet been collected on the fish distribution, but
indications are that we have distributed more than three hundred thousand fish
as larvae consumers in the campaign. We are pushing this system of control in
Ancash and the norther towns in Lima. Mr. Corrigan reports finding 90% of breeding
in Barranca, and 50% in Huache.

I expect to leave for the Department of Libertad to inspect and arrange
matters in the Trujillo office, and from there I shall continue south, probably
arriving in Lima about the end of the month, or early in October. While in Lima
I shall expect to get the question of my unpaid salary satisfactorily arranged.
Yesterday I forwarded you of a copy of the telegram received from the National
City Bank, showing that the draft which the local treasurer gave me on the Treasury
in Lima (a ten day sight draft) was still unpaid after thirty days, which means
that I have not been paid for, May, June, July or August, besides the difference on
the exchange for the balance of the year. Why is this? How is my family expected
live unless I can get my pay and send them something to live on? I believe this
matter should deserve a little more prompt attention from now on.

DIRRECION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
---
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----

As a whole the campaign is going well but the people
must not make the mistake of believing that all is over. Fortunately it seems
that we have no more cases, but the work against the larvae must continue until
we can be sure and until the percentage has been kept down a sufficiently long time
after the last case so as not to have a repetition of what happened last year, and
this year.

In my opinion the most serious possibility remaining is as to whether
or not there may be some focus in Lima or Callao, as a result of the Japanese
who died in Lima in the early dys days of the Ferronafe epidemic. If so this
may show up with the coming of the hot weather there, and the stegomya index
of Lima ought to be determined. The northern Departments are safe and will
remain so with the work which we are doing, providing we get the support which
is necessary.

Mr. Larry Dunn arrived today and will take up a part of the work of
Mr. Pickett and Mr. Corrigan, who will soon return to the Canal Zone. In addition
Mr. Dunn will help us work out some entomological problems on which we have
been working during the campaign.

I am sorry that I can not send you a translation of this, as my in-
terpreter is sick in bed with the grippe.

I sent you a brief letter on the reports which I have on Sr. Cantuarias.
All who came down from up that way complained of his drinking and gambling and
stated that he did no real work as a sanitary inspector. In Tumbes I was told that
he was assuming the role of pharmacist and visiting and treating the sick, and
that he was earning a great deal of money in this way. I have no objection to his
earning money, but if he represents the Health Department he should conduct him-
self accordingly.
div1.closer:
Respectfully submitted, Henry Hanson, M.D.,
Director of Sanitary Campaign for the
Eradication of Yellow Fever.
